instructions.instructions: Select the dropdown terms that fill in the flow chart showing the passage of sperm.

readingPart.reading:
bulbourethral glandsscrotumspermatozoon
epididymisseminal vesiclestestis
prepuceseminiferous tubulesvas deferens
prostate gland

questionContent.questionText:
1. one of a pair of long, tightly coiled tubes above each testis; carries and stores sperm [epididymis]

2. exocrine gland at the base of the male urinary bladder [prostate gland]

3. narrow coiled tubules that produce sperm in the testes [seminiferous tubules]

4. sperm cell [spermatozoon]

5. foreskin [prepuce]

6. male gonad; produces testosterone and sperm cells [testis]

7. paired sac-like exocrine glands that secrete fluid into the vas deferens [seminal vesicles]

8. external sac that contains the testes [scrotum]

9. narrow tube carrying sperm from the epididymis toward the urethra [vas deferens]

10. pair of exocrine glands near the male urethra; Cowper glands [bulbourethral (Cowper) glands]

instructions.instructions: Select from the list of terms to match the descriptions that follow.

readingPart.reading:
ejaculationfraternal twinsinterstitial cells
ejaculatory ductglans penisparenchymal tissue
erectile dysfunctionidentical twinsperineum
flagellum

questionContent.questionText:
1. hair-like projection on a sperm cell that makes it motile [flagellum]

2. sensitive tip of the penis [glans penis]

3. tube through which semen enters the urethra [ejaculatory duct]

4. two infants resulting from division of one fertilized egg into separate embryos [identical twins]

5. external region between the anus and scrotum [perineum]

6. essential distinctive cells of an organ [parenchymal tissue]

7. two infants resulting from fertilization of two ova by two sperm cells [fraternal twins]

8. inability of an adult male to achieve erection; impotence [erectile dysfunction]

9. specialized cells that lie adjacent to the seminiferous tubules [interstitial cells]

10. ejection of sperm and fluid from the urethra [ejaculation]

instructions.instructions: Select from the list of terms to match the descriptions that follow.

readingPart.reading:
aspermiapenisstromal tissue
azoospermiasementesticle
impotencesterilizationtestosterone
oligospermia

questionContent.questionText:
1. male external organ of reproduction [penis]

2. sperm cells and seminal fluid [semen]

3. hormone secreted by interstitial cells of the testes [testosterone]

4. supportive connective tissue of an organ [stromal tissue]

5. lack of semen [aspermia]

6. lack of sperm cells in semen [azoospermia] 

7. procedure that removes a person's ability to produce or release reproductive cells [sterilization]

8. semen with a low concentration of sperm [oligospermia]

9. male gonad [testicle]

10. inability of a male to sustain or achieve an erection [impotence]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed terms with the descriptions that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. inflammation of the testes: [orch]itis

2. inflammation of the tube that carries the spermatozoa to the vas deferens: [epididym]itis

3. resection of the prostate gland: [prostat]ectomy

4. inflammation of the prostate gland: [prostat]itis

5. process of producing (the formation of) sperm cells: [spermato]genesis

6. fixation of undescended testicle: orchio[pexy]

7. inflammation of the glans penis: [balan]itis

8. condition of scanty sperm: [oligo]spermia

9. lack of semen: a[spermia]

10. pertaining to a testicle: [testicul]ar

instructions.instructions: Build medical terms for the following definitions. Parts of the words are given.

questionContent.questionText:
1. [True/False] Cryogenic surgery uses cold temperatures to destroy tissue.

2. [False/True] Estrogen is an example of an androgen.

3. [True/False] Castration (orchiectomy or oophorectomy) is an example of sterilization.

4. [False/True] A teratoma is a benign tumor of the prostate gland.

5. [False/True] Spermolytic means formation of sperm.

6. [False/True] Balanitis is inflammation of a testicle.

7. [True/False] Azoospermia causes infertility.

8. [True/False] Aspermia can result from retrograde ejaculation.

9. [False/True] Seminiferous tubules are the interstitial cells of the testes.

10. [False/True] Testosterone is produced by the parenchymal tissue of the testes.

11. [False/True] Vasectomy produces impotence.

12. [True/False] Vasovasostomy is an anastomosis that can restore fertility (ability to reproduce offspring).

1. castration [Orchiectomy]

2. semen analysis [Test of fertility (reproductive ability)]

3. ejaculation [Ejection of sperm and fluid from the urethra]

4. purulent [Pus-filled]

5. vasectomy [Removal of a piece of the vas deferens]

6. circumcision [Removal of the prepuce]

7. ligation [To tie off or bind]

8. cryosurgery [Destruction of tissue by freezing]

9. seminoma [Malignant tumor of the testis]

10. phimosis [Narrowing (stricture) of the opening of the prepuce over the glans penis]

instructions.instructions: Match the term with its meaning in the dropdown.

readingPart.reading:
adenocarcinoma of the prostateherpes genitalishypospadias
benign prostatic hyperplasiaHPV infectionsyphilis
cryptorchidismhydrocelevaricocele
gonorrhea

questionContent.questionText:
1. prostatic enlargement, nonmalignant [benign prostatic hyperplasia]

2. opening of the urethra on the undersurface of the penis [hypospadias]

3. infection of skin and genital mucosa with HSV [herpes genitalis]

4. malignant tumor of the prostate gland [adenocarcinoma of the prostate]

5. enlarged, swollen veins near the testes [varicocele]

6. sexually transmitted disease with primary stage marked by formation of a chancre [syphilis]

7. infection of the skin and mucous membranes in the anogenital region by human papillomavirus [HPV infection]

8. STI caused by berry-shaped bacteria and marked by inflammation of genital mucosa and mucopurulent discharge [gonorrhea]

9. undescended testicles [cryptorchidism]

10. sac of clear fluid in the scrotum [hydrocele]

instructions.instructions: Select from the listed terms to fit the descriptions that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. PSA [prostate-specific antigen]
2. BPH [benign prostatic hyperplasia]
3. TURP [transurethral resection of the prostate]
4. TRUS [transrectal ultrasound]
5. DRE [digital rectal examination]
6. HSV [herpes simplex virus]
7. STI [sexually transmitted infection]
8. RALP [robotic assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy]

1. High serum levels of this protein indicate prostatic carcinoma [prostate-specific antigen]
2. Noncancerous enlargement of the prostate gland
[benign prostatic hyperplasia]
3. Removal of portions of prostate gland through the urethra [transurethral resection of the prostate]
4. Helpful procedure in guiding a prostatic biopsy needle [transrectal ultrasound]
5. Manual diagnostic procedure to examine the prostate gland [digital rectal examination]
6. Etiologic agent of a sexually transmitted disease characterized by blister formation [herpes simplex virus]
7. Chlamydia, gonorrhea, and syphilis are examples of this general category of infections [sexually transmitted infection]
8. Assisted laparoscopic surgery to remove the prostate gland [robotic assisted laparoscopic prostatectomy]

instructions.instructions: From the dropdown, select the term that best matches the description.

questionContent.questionText:
1. -one [hormone]

2. -stomy [opening]

3. semin/i [semen/seed]

4. -cele [hernia/swelling]

5. -pexy [fixation]

6. -genesis [formation]

7. -plasia [formation]

8. prostat/o [prostate gland]

9. orch/o [testis]

10. terat/o [monster]

11. gon/o [seed]

12. hydr/o [water]

13. pen/o [penis]

14. balan/o [glans penis]

15. varic/o [varicose veins]

16. vas/o [vessel/duct/vas deferens]

17. test/o [testis/testicle]

18. zo/o [animal life]

19. crypt/o [hidden]

20. andr/o [male]

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following word parts.

readingPart.reading:
circumcisionorchiopexyvaricocelectomy
hydrocelectomyphotoselective vaporization of the prostatevasectomy
orchiectomyradical (complete) prostatectomyvasovasostomy

questionContent.questionText:
1. prostate cancer [radical (complete) prostatectomy]

2. cryptorchidism [orchiopexy]

3. sterilization (hormones remain and potency is not impaired) [vasectomy]

4. benign prostatic hyperplasia [photoselective vaporization of the prostate]

5. abnormal collection of fluid in a scrotal sac [hydrocelectomy]

6. reversal of sterilization procedure [vasovasostomy]

7. embryonal carcinoma of the testes [orchiectomy]

8. phimosis [circumcision]

9. ligation of swollen, twisted veins above the testes [varicocelectomy]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed surgical procedures with the following reasons for performing them.

questionContent.questionText:
1. gland at the base of the urinary bladder in males: pro[state] gland

2. coiled tube on top of each testis: epi[didymis]

3. essential tissue of an organ: par[enchymal] tissue

4. foreskin: pre[puce]

5. bacterial infection that invades the urethra and reproductive tract of men and women and is the major cause of nonspecific urethritis in males and cervicitis in females: ch[lamydia]

6. ulcer that forms on genital organs after infection with syphilis: ch[ancre]

7. androgen produced by the interstitial cells of the testis: test[osterone]

8. fluid secreted by male reproductive glands and ejaculated with sperm: se[men/minal fluid]

9. malignant tumor of the testis: sem[inoma]

10. pertaining to the penis: pen[ile]

instructions.instructions: Use the given definitions to complete the terms. Check your answers carefully.

questionContent.questionText:
1. When Fred was a newborn infant, his doctors could feel only one testicle within the scrotum and suggested close monitoring of his condition of [cryptorchidism/gonorrhea/benign prostatic hyperplasia].

2. Bob had many sexual partners, one of whom had been diagnosed with [chlamydia/testosterone/phimosis] , a highly communicable STI.

3. At age 65, Mike had some difficulty with urgency and discomfort when urinating. His doctor did a digital rectal examination to examine his [prostate gland/urinary bladder/vas deferens].

4. Just after Nick’s birth, his parents had a difficult time deciding whether to have their infant son undergo [circumcision/TURP/castration].

5. Ted noticed a hard ulcer on his penis and made an appointment with his doctor, a [urologist/gastroenterologist/gynecologist] . The doctor viewed a specimen of the ulcer under the microscope and did a blood test, which revealed that Ted had contracted [syphilis/gonorrhea/herpes genitalis] , so the ulcer was a [chancre/blister/seminoma].

6. After his fifth child was born, Art decided to have a [vasectomy/vasovasostomy/hydrocelectomy] to prevent conception of another child. A/an [urologist/nephrologist/abdominal surgeon] performed the procedure to cut and ligate the [vas deferens/urethra/epididymis] .

7. Twenty-six-year-old Lance noticed a hard testicular mass. His physician prescribed a brief trial with [antibiotics/antibodies/pain killers] to rule out [epididymitis/testicular cancer/varicocele] . The mass remained and Lance underwent [orchiectomy/epididymectomy/prostatectomy]. The mass was a [seminoma/prostate cancer/hydrocele].

8. Sarah and Steve had been trying to conceive a child for 7 years. Steve had a [semen analysis/digital rectal examination/TURP], which revealed 25% normal sperm count with 10% motility. He was told he had [oligospermia/phimosis/azoospermia].

9. To boost his sperm count, Steve was given [testosterone/estrogen/progesterone] . As a side effect, this [androgen/progestin/enzyme] gave him a case of acne lasting several months.

10. Sarah eventually became pregnant. An ultrasound examination showed two embryos with two separate placentas and in separate [amniotic/peritoneal/scrotal] sacs. Sarah gave birth to two healthy [fraternal/identical/perineal] twin girls.

instructions.instructions: Select the correct term(s) to complete the following sentences.
